HJ_comment: Gardens and cultivated areas; occasional weed.
Garden and waste places. Common.
Walker Sucia 2018. Atkinson Richardson Marsh, Lopez 1992.
Salt or brackish marshes, sometimes in exposed open mudflats; occasional.
Abundant. Reported as Salicornia virginica.
Peck just above beach at Argyle date? Represented by herbarium collections but not considered established.
Once established near Roche Harbour, Peck collections 1923. Not found since.
Locations witheld Orcas, San Juan, Lopez, Decatur. See S. x howellii
Dry transitional forest, rocky slopes above salt water. Vars tripartita and crassicaulis both present.
Roadsides, grassy thickets, Orcas, San Juan, Skull
Forestry introduction in stream valleys near Cascade lake, Orcas; for a time established there but no longer present.
Introduced garden species; excaping and occasionally persisting in residential waste places.
Rare; shaded, wet rock crevices; Mt. Constitution, Mt. Dallas and Willow Island. Zika Turtleback, Orcas 2021.
Fairly common throughout on prairies, locally common on Mt Constitution.
Occasional in less disturbed meadows; San Juan to Stuart.
Local; Mt Constitution; stony ground. Reported as A. rosea in WPofSJI
Occasional in towns.
Occasional adventive on sandy soils, San Juan.
Localized but well represented on high, rocky ridges of Mt Constitution.
Towns and roadsides; widespread mostly on Lopez but well established and increasing on San Juan.

Locally common Friday Harbour; occasional elsewhere. Earliest collection Peck, Shaw Island 1923. Olga, Orcas Tolle 2019 iNaturalist observation. DeVito Cattle Point, San Juan 2020 iNaturalist observation.
Historically present on Orcas; weedy fields.
Rare and local near the summit of Mt Constitution on steep[ rocky cliffs. HJ obs 1984.
Common; open, rocky sites or gravelly outwash meadows.
Rare in summit area of Mt Constitution; steep, rocky cliffs and talus. Reported as Aster sibiricus var mertius
Beattie Orcas 1909.
F. germanica reported. Moist, open places and fields. Comp. F. pyramidata
Common throughout.
Shaded rocky talus and cliffs, local on Mt Constitution.
Meadows and forest edges; known from historic report in Yellow-Wasp group. DT 1956. reported as H. albertinium Farr.
Vernal pools and damp, open ruderal sites; widespread but irregular.
Peck Friday Harbour, San Juan 1923.
Fairly common; roadsides, fields and strand.
Rocky talus high on Mt Constitution; local. Reported as S. spathulata DC. var. s.
Widespread but uncommon; landward edges of salt marshes and other low, wet sites.
Common weed; waste places throughout.
Wet open places or ditches; often in thickeds; common.
Moist, open places and ditches; rare on San Juan. Atkinson 1992 Symphyotrichum hallii (A. Gray) G.L. Nesom restricted location.
Gregg Friday Harbor, 2 mi S of Limekiln Light, San Juan Island 1962 voucher at FMNH
dry, rocky edge of forest and meadow; rare; known from historic reports in Wasp-Yellow group. DT 1956
Rare, wet rock seeps, upper elevations, Mt Constitution. Originally collected by Pope 1904.
iNaturalist report from Rocky Bay, San Juan 2019. Atkinson & Sharpe dedicated searches have not located this species on the San Juan Islands. A. californica known from Whidbey Island 2015.
Peck Cattle Point, San Juan 1923.
Dry meadows, coastal strand and waste places; common throughout. Expect A. spectabilis on strand.
Marschner Flattop Island 2006. Note to expect on strand in A. menziesii text.
Dry, open places; rare; San Juan.
Wet places, in thickets, along ponds or lakes, occasional on larger islands.
Damp, shady woods, especially Alder or mixed composition; var. austiniae at a few places on Orcas in dry meadows.
San Juan, Shaw, Lopez. Recent records Denton and Atinson.
Vernally moist depressions in meadows; rare in the Yellow-Wasp group.
Zika Spencer Spit, Lopez Island 2000.
Walker Jones Island vernally wet area 2018
Uncommon on strand; mostly San Juan and Lopez but occurs throughout.
Strands. Colonizing the area from Strait of Juan de Fuca and outer coast where more common. Widespread on San Juans.
McCutchen iNaturalist observaion Three Corners Lake Rd, San Juan 2021.
Wet, open places; occasional.
Peck Shaw Island 1923. Reported on CPNWH as Descurainia incisa (Engelm. ex A. Gray) Britton ssp. incisa
D. stenoloba reported historic record for Wasp-Yellow Island group, grassy open bluffs. Peck Friday Harbour 1923. Dodd & Tusler report from Coon Island.
Peck Friday Harbour 1923.
Strand, rocky coastal bluffs, less often sandy, upland meadows.
Rotting logs in lakes or boggy edge; rare. Peck1923 Sportsmans Lake.
Open, gravelly slopes, rare. No records on Floristic Atlas of the San Juan Islands.
Peck roadside Friday Harbour 1923.
Abundant; dry, exposed slopes to shady woods and roadsides.
Moist mixed forest edge and adjacent gravelly slopes; rare; Mt Dallas-Cady Mt and higher elevation on Orcas.
Northwest Stuart Island in grass on airfield 1985. Not relocated in searches 1992, 1995. =Mauranthemum paludosum (Poir.) Vogt & Oberpr. This species is not considered naturalized in the flora.
Dry, gravelly meadows, occasionally open coniferous woods, common.
Dry meadows, occasional. Refered to C. semidecandrum in A&S 1993.
Zika Friday Harbour 2001, presumably spread from cultivation, steep weedy bank, full sun, with Festuca arundinacea, Vicia sativa, V. villosa.
Grassy waste ground, Fairgrounds, Argyle Road, Friday Harbor, San Juan Zika 2001.
Giblin Blind Island, Frye Friday Harbour 1905 reported as Minuatia r.
Meadows and dry, open coniferous forest; substantial colony at Iceberg Point, rare on San Juan.
Occasional roadsides and waste places.
Sandy or gravelly, often hard-packed waste soils. CPNWH shows no nearby locations. CDC Explorer no records. Exclude?
Common, salt marshes gravelly meadows and rocky costal bluffs.
Edges of swamps and other wet places; often in heavy shade. Reported as S. bongardiana.
Rare; known from a single wet meadow station near Cold Springs, Mt Constitution. Also Naas collections Agate Beach, Lopez 1994. Lawrence Stuart Island 1904.
PZ Friday Harbour vacant weedy lot, full sun 2002.
Rare; known from Peck's 1923 collection in a meadow southeast of Roche Harbour, San Juan.
Moist, mossy coniferous woods near Summit lake, Orcas; rare. Reported as C. unalaschkensis Ledeb. (possible?)
Scattered and rare on larger islands in mixed Alder-Fir forests; most common in the northern tier.

Rare, salt marshes and seeps along shoreline.
Reported as C. lasiocarpa occasional on Orcas sphagnum bogs and fens.
Henderson Eastsound, Orcas 1892. Only low elevation record in Salish Basin.
Scattered and uncommon; moist spots in alder woodlands,seeps and pond borders.
Sportsman Lake, Egg Lake San Juan. Lakes at summit Mt Constitution.

Open woods and moist, shadeed slopes near salt water; known from old records in the Wasp-Yellow group. No current records CPNWH.

Johansen two sites several miles apart SW of Friday Harbour, San Juan 1946.
Dry, rocky sites, often near salt water; most common on Orcas and San Juan Islands but found throughout.
Boggy meadows, usually where disturbed; rare; Orcas, San Juan and Lopez. Henderson 1892 East Sound.
Damp meadows and ditches; occasional on San Juan, Errata of FofPNW says re-id Centaurium pulchellum.
Open sites throughout; common.
Martinez Orcas iNaturalist report 2018. No herbarium records for area found.
Cattle Point, San Juan iNaturalist report 2020.

Report of M. sibiricum Komarov = M. spicatum var exalbescens. Common to abundant especially on Orcas. Note AC 1986 posits that this is a native species. M. spicatum var s. also reported lakes and ponds; occasional.
Moist meadows; occasional. var. douglasii Lopez and San Juan. Iceberg Point, San Juan Denton.
Aquatic, reported from Spencer Lake, Blakely Island (J.R. Slater, T.C. Frye, R. Phillips) Reported as I. echinospora var. braunii
Fairly common ditches and other wet places.
Widespread throughout the archipeligo, coastal marshes to bogs near the summit of Mt Constitution; very common. Also reported as J. lesueurii Boland.dunes near American Camp, San Juan.
Wet or boggy soils; infrequent.
Abundant throughout; farm fields, ditches, disturbed woodlands.
Abundant throughout; farm fields, ditches, disturbed woodlands.

Salt or brackish marshes; uncommon but widespread. AC has a collection at UBC from Lopez.
Wright Eagle Cove Beach, San Juan iNaturalist reports 2019-2020.

Low, wet places; occasional on larger islands.
Zike Friday Harbour mowed waste ground, full sun 2001. Synonym? Not in Washington checklist.

Rare; grassy bulffs by sea; originally colledcted by Capt. Archibald Menzies on Orcas Island 1792. Recently reported from Bald Hill, San Juan Island and Orcas Island. Formerly present near Cattle Point.

Common, open places. Strand, moist meadows or outcrops.

Friday Harbour Marine Laboratory grounds. West across cove from main lab grounds.E facing slope. With moss covered rocks under Arbutus menziesii and Pseudotsuga menziesii. Abundant, growing with Plectritis congesta. Gage 1997. Planted?

E. ciliatum var glandulosum often common from higher elevation wetlands on Mt Constitution and low elevation fresh or salt-water marshes and ditches. SA Eastsound Marsh, mosit soils, with Boisduvalia stricta. date?

Common to abundant; dry, sandy areas to moist woods and boggy lake shores.

Common to abundant; wooded roadside, disturbed and cut over forest.

Floberg, Boulder Island off Lopez Island. Open grassy 4 acre (?) island with rock/cliff shores. Only trees are several dozen stunted Pseudotsuga menziesii. Upland meadows on Mt Constitution, rare on upper elevation sloope elsewhere.
Gage and Rodman Summit of Mount Constitution, Moran State Park, Orcas Island 1992.

Widespread but thinly distributed; rocky benchland and dry meadows. Festuca ovina used to be interpreted very broadly in North America, including almost any fine-leaved fescue that lacked rhizomes. Consequently, much of the information reported for F. ovina, and many of the specimens identified as such, belong to other species.
Uncommon; mostly in satt marshes but sometimes at waste places.
Fields anf roadsides, sometimes saline sites;occasional. Reported as H. geniculatum
Fairly common weed of vacant lots and roadsides. Sometimes in saline soil.
see H. m. ssp leporinum

Zika Roche Harbour 2001. Gardens upslope, limestone ledges by the sea, escaped from gardens upslope, well established on limestone ledges by the sea, with Stellaria media, Erodium cicutarium, Cerastium semidecandrum.

Status unknown; collected near Eagle Cove, San Juan Island. Reported from the southern edge of San Juan; range imperfectly known. Zika near False Bay 2016. Nobel Deadman Bay, San Juan iNaturalist report 2019.
Zostera japonica and Z. nana reported Friday Harbour Marine Lab. Both synonymous w/ Nz. j. Zostera nana rare collected at Crescent Bay, Orcas Island.
